title: 103_hr4897
content: The "Child Support Enforcement Act of 1994" allows for the seizure of lottery winnings, settlements, payouts, and sale of forfeited property to pay child support arrearages. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include procedures for imposing a lien on lottery winnings or gambling payouts to pay child support arrearages. The distributor must suspend payment until the state child support agency confirms the debt. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act includes procedures for withholding payments from insurance policies or settlements to pay child support arrearages. Payments must be suspended until the state agency confirms the debt. The amended Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act allows for withholding payments from insurance policies or settlements to pay child support arrearages. Payments must be suspended until the state agency confirms the debt, and the payor must withhold and pay the amount to the State agency for distribution. The State agency can withhold payments from individuals owing child support arrearages or property forfeited due to a criminal conviction. The withheld amount is paid to the State agency for distribution. The State agency can withhold payments from individuals with child support arrearages. If there is an arrearage, the agency can sell the property and pay the remaining proceeds or the arrearage amount to the State agency for distribution. Any person required to make payment in respect to a decedent must suspend the payment until confirmation from the State agency regarding any child support arrearage. If there is an arrearage, the person should withhold and pay the lesser of the payment amount or the arrearage to the State agency for distribution. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS RELATING TO PROFESSIONAL, OCCUPATIONAL, BUSINESS, AND DRIVER'S LICENSES. Section 466(a) of the Social Security Act is amended to include restrictions on issuing or renewing occupational licenses for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support or individuals delinquent in child support payments. The State motor vehicle department may not issue or renew driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with outstanding warrants related to child support proceedings. This restriction can be lifted if a State prosecutor or court consents to release the hold on the license, or an expedited review is completed while granting a 60-day temporary license. The State motor vehicle department can suspend driver's licenses or vehicle registrations for noncustodial parents with child support warrants. They can issue temporary licenses or registrations if needed. The State motor vehicle department can issue temporary licenses or vehicle registrations to individuals with child support warrants pending compliance with the order or warrant removal. The attachment of bank accounts is addressed in Section 4. Section 466(a) (42 U.S.C. 666(a)), as amended, allows for the seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears through an administrative process, with notice and an opportunity for the account holder to be heard. The amended Section 466(a) allows for the seizure of funds in a bank account to pay child support arrears, with notice and an opportunity for the account holder to challenge the seizure. If the account holder fails to successfully challenge the seizure, the institution may have to pay the arrearage amount from the account to the entity with the right to collect. SEC. 5. Reporting of child support obligations to credit bureaus, amends the Social Security Act to require courts and agencies to report individual names and amounts of child support obligations to consumer reporting agencies. SEC. 6. Liability of grandparents for financial support of their grandchildren. SEC. 6 amends the Social Security Act to hold each parent responsible for supporting their child if the individual is unable to do so. This does not apply if the State plan specifies otherwise.
